examples.en: I’m working hard studying kanji on WaniKani.
examples.ja: 鰐蟹で漢字を猛勉強中です。

meaning_mnemonic: This is it. You're finally here. This is the moment where you learn the true meaning behind WaniKani!
reading_mnemonic: You should be able to read this on your own. And seriously... if you ever get this one wrong we're gonna show up at your house and look down at you with really, really disappointed looks on our faces. Don't let us down, kids.

examples.en: It seems that my wife is committing adultery.
examples.ja: どうやら妻が不倫をしているようなんです。

meaning_mnemonic: If you do <kanji>not</kanji> have any <kanji>ethics</kanji> you'll probably do something crappy, like commit <vocabulary>adultery</vocabulary>. Usually only unethical people would cheat on their spouse, right?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please abide by business ethics properly.
examples.ja: ちゃんと職業倫理を守ってください。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Ethics</kanji> and <kanji>reason</kanji> together in a person make them have very strong <vocabulary>ethics</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>morals</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: One sided nutrition isn’t good for you.
examples.ja: 栄養が偏るのは良くない。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>biased</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to be biased</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be prejudiced</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You meet someone who claims <vocabulary>to be biased</vocabulary> about everything. You ask them why and they say, "I'm a <reading>cutter, yo</reading> (かたよ)! I cut everything in half and only like one of 'em. But I guess if you wanna call that biased go ahead, man." Huh, okay.

examples.en: That is called prejudice.
examples.ja: それが偏見というものです。

examples.en: There is no world where prejudice doesn't exist.
examples.ja: 偏見が全くない世界なんてものは存在しない。

examples.en: She seems to be prejudiced against Asian people.
examples.ja: 彼女はアジア人に偏見があるようだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>biased</kanji> way of <kanji>see</kanji>ing is also known as <vocabulary>prejudice</vocabulary>, or just <vocabulary>bias</vocabulary>.

偏見 is often used to describe unfair judgments or opinions based on stereotypes rather than facts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Stereotypes make people narrow-minded.
examples.ja: ステレオタイプは人間を偏狭にします。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Narrow</kanji> <kanji>biased</kanji> people are considered to be <vocabulary>narrow minded</vocabulary> and they're usually disliked for their <vocabulary>intolerance</vocabulary> of other cultures and anything unfamiliar to them.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 狭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The only place <vocabulary>narrow minded</vocabulary> people will go in Japan is <reading>Kyo</reading>to (きょう). It's where all the tour guides say to go, and they're too narrow minded to listen to anyone else. So they see Kyoto and head back home right away without seeing anywhere else.

examples.en: I’m worried because my kids tend to have unbalanced diets.
examples.ja: 子供が偏食がちなので困っています。

meaning_mnemonic: People who are <kanji>biased</kanji> about what they <kanji>eat</kanji> usually only eat sweet stuff like candy and ice cream. This <vocabulary>picky eating</vocabulary> gives them a really <vocabulary>unbalanced diet</vocabulary>. Candy and ice cream are okay, but you have to be open to eating other things too.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It seems like Messi made a comment hinting at his transfer.
examples.ja: メッシが、移籍を示唆するコメントをしたようだ。

meaning_mnemonic: Someone prone to <kanji>indicate</kanji> and <kanji>instigate</kanji> will have lots of <vocabulary>suggestions</vocabulary> for other people. By dropping <vocabulary>hint</vocabulary>s, they can indicate problems and instigate fights among people. Their <vocabulary>implication</vocabulary>s do a lot of harm.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 示 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Someone keeps coming up to you making <vocabulary>suggestion</vocabulary>s and dropping <vocabulary>hint</vocabulary>s that you should buy a <reading>shee</reading>p (し). It happens so much that you finally decide to grab the hint-droppers arm and... oh my gosh, that's a hoof. They're a sheep!

examples.en: What do you think would happen if Mt. Fuji erupted?
examples.ja: 富士山が噴火したらどうなると思いますか。

meaning_mnemonic: When a volcano <kanji>erupt</kanji>s with <kanji>fire</kanji> it makes a really big <vocabulary>eruption</vocabulary>. You should probably start running.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I took a picture of the volcanic smoke rising over Sakurajima.
examples.ja: 噴煙を上げる桜島の写真を撮りました。

meaning_mnemonic: Sometimes volcanoes <kanji>erupt</kanji> with just <kanji>smoke</kanji> instead of lava or fire. That's called <vocabulary>volcanic smoke</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please show me how to spray tear gas.
examples.ja: 催涙スプレーの噴射方法を教えてください。

meaning_mnemonic: When something <kanji>erupt</kanji>s and <kanji>shoots</kanji> a bunch of water or lava out it comes out in a huge <vocabulary>jet</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>spray</vocabulary>s everything.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Let’s meet at the water fountain over there.
examples.ja: あそこの噴水で待ち合わせをしましょう。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Water</kanji> <kanji>erupts</kanji> from <vocabulary>water fountains</vocabulary>. Sometimes they're big eruptions and sometimes they're small, but they're always fun to watch and enjoy in the hot summer.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Is it true that gas spews out of black holes?
examples.ja: ブラックホールからガスが噴出しているって本当ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: When something <kanji>erupt</kanji>s out an <kanji>exit</kanji> it usually had to fight pretty hard to get to that exit. That's why it ends up <vocabulary>spewing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>gushing</vocabulary> all over the place.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I consulted my wife and we’ve decided to take charge of an orphan.
examples.ja: 妻と相談して、孤児を引き取ることにしました。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>orphan</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> is sadly still an <vocabulary>orphan</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m writing a novel set on a solitary island.
examples.ja: 今は孤島を舞台とした小説を書いています。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>orphan</kanji> <kanji>island</kanji> is one that's all alone, without any other island friends or family. That's what makes it a <vocabulary>solitary island</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 島 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

There are a few <vocabulary>solitary island</vocabulary>s off the coast of Japan that are actually considered to be a part of <reading>To</reading>kyo (とう). Usually people think Tokyo is just the big city on the mainland, but it includes these little, lonely islands too!

examples.en: I’ve always led an isolated life.
examples.ja: ずっと孤独な人生を送ってきたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>orphan</kanji> who's <kanji>alone</kanji> is trapped in a world of <vocabulary>isolation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>loneliness</vocabulary>. Having no parents is hard enough, but not having anyone else is even lonelier.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A certain incident occurred, and I found myself alone and friendless at work.
examples.ja: ある事件があって、職場で孤立してしまったんです。

meaning_mnemonic: When <kanji>orphan</kanji>s <kanji>stand</kanji>, they stand in <vocabulary>isolation</vocabulary> — <vocabulary>alone</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>friendless</vocabulary>. Orphans don't have any parents, so this world can be a pretty cruel place for them. It's really sad.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: What do you think you can do to conquer your laziness?
examples.ja: どうすれば怠惰を克服できるのでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>lazy</kanji> <kanji>lazy</kanji> person is plagued with never ending <vocabulary>laziness</vocabulary>. They never get up. They just move slowly around the floor.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I am responsible for this failure of neglecting to check it.
examples.ja: この失敗は確認を怠った私の責任です。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>neglect</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to be negligent</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to neglect</vocabulary> something.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

If you always seem <vocabulary>to be negligent</vocabulary> to your kids you'll end up with this situation. It's winter and your kid comes home from school covered in snow and sneezing. "<reading>Oh, coat</reading>... (おこた)" you say. You didn't give them a coat when they went out today. Maybe if you weren't so negligent that wouldn't have happened.

examples.en: Apparently, there are times the black hole tears stars into pieces.
examples.ja: ブラックホールが、恒星をばらばらに引き裂くことがあるらしい。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>constant</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> is the kind that stays in one place. It's just a regular <vocabulary>star</vocabulary>, like the north star or our sun, not a comet or an asteroid.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It is an established practice at my company to have a Christmas party every year.
examples.ja: うちの会社では、毎年恒例のクリスマス会があるんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Constant</kanji> <kanji>example</kanji>s that you use all the time end up becoming part of an <vocabulary>established practice</vocabulary>. You constantly use them so it just stays that way after a while.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I pray for perpetual peace.
examples.ja: 恒久の平和を祈っています。

meaning_mnemonic: A thing that's <kanji>constant</kanji> for a <kanji>long time</kanji> becomes <vocabulary>permanent</vocabulary>. Leave a shoe on the sidewalk for a long time? Permanently stuck there. Constantly making dumb faces? Permanently stuck like that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: With this system we can consistently keep it at room temperature.
examples.ja: このシステムで部屋の温度を恒常に保っています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Keeping things <kanji>constant</kanji> and <kanji>normal</kanji> ensures <vocabulary>constancy</vocabulary>.

恒常 is a formal word used to describe something that remains <vocabulary>constant</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>unchanging</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I had no will to study, I simply attended university out of habit.
examples.ja: 僕は、勉強への意欲は無く、ただ惰性で大学へ通っていました。

meaning_mnemonic: If you have the <kanji>nature</kanji> of being <kanji>lazy</kanji> it will become a <vocabulary>habit</vocabulary>. The <vocabulary>momentum</vocabulary> created by your natural laziness will make it so you can't break out of your lazy cycle.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Holding your pee is bad for your health.
examples.ja: おしっこを我慢するのは体に悪い。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>I</kanji> get <kanji>ridiculed</kanji> a lot, but it makes me have really strong <vocabulary>endurance</vocabulary>. If you get picked on a lot, just say, "I have <vocabulary>patience</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>self control</vocabulary>, and I can make it through this."
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It’s impossible for me to proudly boast about my own affair.
examples.ja: 自分の不倫を得意気に自慢するとか、ありえないんだけど。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>ridicule</kanji> everyone but your<kanji>self</kanji> because you have so much <vocabulary>pride</vocabulary>. When you talk about yourself you only <vocabulary>boast</vocabulary> because there's nothing to ridicule. That's how great you think you are.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: That waitress’ movements were really slow so she was fired.
examples.ja: あのウエイトレスは動きが緩慢なので首にしたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: When your <kanji>laziness</kanji> is <kanji>loose</kanji> you can't pull yourself together and you end up moving really <vocabulary>slow</vocabulary>. Your arms and legs get loose and your movements become <vocabulary>sluggish</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 緩 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You've become so <vocabulary>slow</vocabulary> that you can only eat things out of the <reading>can</reading> (かん). You don't have the energy to cook and your arms are all loose so it doesn't even matter if you weren't moving so slowly. So just lay there, eating slowly from a can.

examples.en: Isn’t that police negligence?
examples.ja: それは警察の怠慢なんじゃないんですか。

meaning_mnemonic: You ignore everything around you because you are <kanji>lazy</kanji> with <kanji>laziness</kanji>. That's too much lazy for one person so you're prone to <vocabulary>negligence</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>procrastination</vocabulary>. You definitely can't manage to take care of things when you're this lazy.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I suffer from chronic gastroenteritis.
examples.ja: 私は慢性胃腸炎を患っているんです。

meaning_mnemonic: If it's in your <kanji>nature</kanji> to <kanji>ridicule</kanji> people, it will become a <vocabulary>chronic</vocabulary> problem. You can't change something that's so embedded in who you are, which is a shame, since you're a jerk.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why did you speak up to protect him?
examples.ja: 君はどうして彼を擁護するような発言をしたんだい。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Embrace</kanji> your duty to <kanji>defend</kanji> your country and prepare for its <vocabulary>protection</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>defense</vocabulary>. You love your country, so you'll do what you have to in order to <vocabulary>support</vocabulary> its defense.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The scene in that movie where the two leading actors exchanged a sweet embrace was so beautiful.
examples.ja: その映画の、主役の二人が甘い抱擁を交わすシーンがとても美しかったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>embrace</kanji> and a <kanji>hug</kanji> are pretty much the same thing. So you're still going to <vocabulary>embrace</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>hug</vocabulary> people!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 抱 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who gives the best <vocabulary>hug</vocabulary>s in the world? It's the people at <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう)! Since they know you best, they also know when and how you like your hugs.

examples.en: I'm sure that they are just trying to support the candidate.
examples.ja: どうせ出馬者を擁立しようとしているだけだろう。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>embrace</kanji> someone to keep them <kanji>stand</kanji>ing. You're <vocabulary>backing</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>supporting</vocabulary> this person, so no matter what happens you've gotta keep them on their feet.

擁立 is a formal word for backing someone up for a position, usually in politics or organizations. It's used when people unite to promote or nominate someone as a leader or as a political candidate.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Kanagawa Prefecture has a larger population than Chiba Prefecture.
examples.ja: 神奈川県は千葉県よりも多い人口を擁しています。

examples.en: The favorite for the championship is the genius batter Tofugu Academy has.
examples.ja: 優勝候補は、天才バッターを擁するトーフグ学園です。

meaning_mnemonic: To do an <kanji>embrace</kanji> is <vocabulary>to have</vocabulary> that person or animal in your arms. You hug it and then run away with it. It's yours now.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: This car’s tires are pretty unique.
examples.ja: この車のタイヤはちょっと特殊なんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>especially</kanji> <kanji>special</kanji> thing is even more <vocabulary>special</vocabulary> and probably a lot more <vocabulary>unique</vocabulary> than ordinary special things.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: That's an admirable woman.
examples.ja: あいつは殊勝な女だったよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You're <kanji>especially</kanji> <kanji>win</kanji>ning when you selflessly devote yourself or overcome personal weaknesses. That's what makes it <vocabulary>admirable</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>praiseworthy</vocabulary>!

殊勝 is a formal term often used to describe someone's commendable endurance, sincere attitude, good intentions, or virtuous actions.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The manuscript was rejected the other day.
examples.ja: こないだの原稿は没になってしまった。

examples.en: I'm sorry, but I'm afraid you're going to have to discard this idea for now.
examples.ja: 申し訳ありませんが、この案は一旦没にしてください。

examples.en: The singer is said to have died on December 1, 2015, but the facts are not clear.
examples.ja: その歌手は、2015年12月1日没、とされているが、真相は定かではない。

meaning_mnemonic: When a plant or an animal <kanji>die</kanji>s you have to <vocabulary>discard</vocabulary> it. You can't just keep it sitting around the house after <vocabulary>death</vocabulary>, that's weird.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: A commemoration exhibition is planned 50 years after their death.
examples.ja: 没後50年を記念した展覧会を予定しています。

meaning_mnemonic: All the art, music, or books that come out <kanji>after</kanji> a person <kanji>die</kanji>s are considered to be released <vocabulary>after death</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>posthumously</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Many soldiers who were killed in action are buried here.
examples.ja: たくさんの戦没した兵士たちがここに埋められています。

meaning_mnemonic: When a person <kanji>die</kanji>s in a <kanji>war</kanji> they're considered to have been <vocabulary>killed in action</vocabulary>. There are lots of memorials around the world for people who died this way.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There’s a person who predicted the sinking of the Titanic.
examples.ja: タイタニック号の沈没を予言していた人がいるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>sink</kanji> and <kanji>die</kanji> it's because you were <vocabulary>sinking</vocabulary> in the ocean or a pool or something. It's important to notice you're <vocabulary>going down</vocabulary> so you don't die like that.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If I leave now I think I can arrive by sunset.
examples.ja: 今出発すれば、日没までには着けると思います。

meaning_mnemonic: At night the <kanji>sun</kanji> <kanji>die</kanji>s at <vocabulary>sunset</vocabulary>. Don't worry, it will be reborn tomorrow morning at sunrise and everything will be okay.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If you can immerse yourself in things you like, you'll be happy.
examples.ja: 好きなことに没頭できるなんて、幸せですね。

meaning_mnemonic:
All the extra things <kanji>die</kanji> in the <kanji>head</kanji> when one is <vocabulary>immersing oneself</vocabulary> in one thing. That way, the thing they're focusing on is the only thing in their brain.

没頭 is a relatively formal word that means being deeply absorbed or engrossed in something. It's often positive and describes a state where someone is so focused on an activity they lose track of time or forget about everything else.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this word.

examples.en: Do you think Japan is really collapsing?
examples.ja: 本当に日本は没落していると思いますか？

meaning_mnemonic: A building or civilization that <kanji>die</kanji>s and then <kanji>falls</kanji> is in a state of <vocabulary>ruin</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>collapse</vocabulary>. Like the Mayans or the Western Roman Empire. They fell pretty hard.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I had double eyelids surgically implanted with plastic surgery.
examples.ja: 整形手術で二重の埋没手術をしました。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>bury</kanji> things into people who look like they've <kanji>die</kanji>d. It's called <vocabulary>implantation</vocabulary>. They're not really dead though. This is surgery and they'll wake up and go about their lives with whatever that thing was that you put in them.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 埋 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Wait that's not a person you're <vocabulary>embedding</vocabulary> things into. It's a bunch of <reading>mi</reading>ce (まい). I guess that's okay. Just don't go putting the mice into people. That's... don't cross that line.

examples.en: Bears appear frequently in large quantities all over Japan.
examples.ja: 日本各地でクマが大量出没している。

meaning_mnemonic: Animals <kanji>exit</kanji> the mountains into your land and never seem to <kanji>die</kanji>! They end up <vocabulary>appearing frequently</vocabulary> in your garden, eating all your yummy carrots and watermelons, and then make their exit back into the hills. They're <vocabulary>infesting</vocabulary> your home now and you don't know what to do!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I forfeited my cell phone to the teacher.
examples.ja: 先生に携帯電話を没収されました。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>obtain</kanji> something acting like that person had <kanji>die</kanji>d, it's called <vocabulary>confiscation</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>forfeiture</vocabulary>. Maybe if they were alive, you think, they wouldn't have let me take it. Well they are still alive so it's theirs and you can't keep it forever.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Do you want to succeed so badly that you’re willing to sacrifice someone?
examples.ja: だれかを犠牲にしてまで成功したいかい？

meaning_mnemonic: Who do you <kanji>sacrifice</kanji> as an <kanji>offering</kanji> to the gods? A poor <vocabulary>victim</vocabulary> will be your <vocabulary>sacrifice</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m just about to go hunting.
examples.ja: これから猟に行くところだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: My uncle is a hunter.
examples.ja: 私の叔父は猟師です。

meaning_mnemonic: If you can <kanji>teach</kanji> <kanji>hunting</kanji> then you must be a really accomplished <vocabulary>hunter</vocabulary> yourself.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: What do you think can be done to prevent the poaching of elephants?
examples.ja: どうすれば象の密猟を防止できると思いますか。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Hunting</kanji> in <kanji>secrecy</kanji> is only done through illegal <vocabulary>poaching</vocabulary>. If you weren't poaching protected animals you wouldn't have to do it secretly.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Hunting of this bird is prohibited.
examples.ja: この鳥の狩猟は禁じられています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Hunting</kanji> where you <kanji>hunt</kanji> is still <vocabulary>hunting</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 狩 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

When <vocabulary>hunting</vocabulary> make sure you know where the water <reading>chu</reading>tes (しゅ) are located. You'll need to use those chutes to move quickly during the hunt.

examples.en: It’s said that hunting dogs typically bark a lot.
examples.ja: 一般的に猟犬はよく吠えると言われています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>hunting</kanji> <kanji>dog</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hunting dog</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 犬 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Who has the best <vocabulary>hunting dog</vocabulary> in the world? <reading>Ken</reading> (けん) from Street Fighter! His dog is also named Ken, because that's how Ken and Ken do things.

examples.en: Dekopon is a kind of mandarin orange that originated in Japan.
examples.ja: デコポンは日本発祥のみかんの品種です。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>auspicious</kanji> <kanji>departure</kanji> from another world is your <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary> story. You originally came from another place, and you had to leave there gloriously before you could enter this world.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The police are trying to hide their own scandal.
examples.ja: 警察は自分たちの不祥事を隠そうとしているんだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>not</kanji>-<kanji>auspicious</kanji> <kanji>occurrence</kanji> is a <vocabulary>scandal</vocabulary>. A scandal is pretty much the opposite of an auspicious occurrence.

不祥事 refers to a scandal that brings about dishonor, particularly to institutions, organizations, or public figures. It often involves misconduct, corruption, or other unethical behavior that has a significant negative impact on their public image.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Please do not disturb order.
examples.ja: 秩序を乱すようなことはしないでください。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>preface</kanji> of <kanji>order</kanji> is still <vocabulary>order</vocabulary>. Because order is always prefaced by more order. Order keeps us all in check.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There are plenty of emergency provisions.
examples.ja: 食糧の備蓄は十分にあります。

examples.en: Staple food shortages are not just a problem in this country.
examples.ja: 食糧不足はこの国だけの問題ではない。

examples.en: It seems that the upper echelons of the military are refusing to distribute rations to all of their soldiers.
examples.ja: 軍の上層部が、兵士全てに食糧を配給するのを拒んでいるようだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Provisions</kanji> you can <kanji>eat</kanji> are still <vocabulary>provisions</vocabulary> and sometimes called <vocabulary>rations</vocabulary>, especially when troops are eating them.

This word often refers to <vocabulary>staple foods</vocabulary> like rice and wheat.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You have to take a look at these huge documents from now on.
examples.ja: これからこの膨大な資料に目を通さなくてはいけないんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: A thing that <kanji>swell</kanji>s <kanji>big</kanji> ends up being <vocabulary>huge</vocabulary> or at least really <vocabulary>bulky</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I overate and my stomach is swollen like a balloon.
examples.ja: 食べ過ぎてお腹がパンパンに膨れています。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>swell</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to swell</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to expand</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Someone comes up to you and asks, "Hey, do you want your stomach to swell like that?" How dare they ask you about your stomach. You respond with, "<reading>F@#$</reading> (ふく) you!" It's none of their business how much you want your stomach to expand.

examples.en: The universe is expanding.
examples.ja: 宇宙は膨張しています。

meaning_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>swell</kanji> and <kanji>stretch</kanji> if you want to see any kind of <vocabulary>expansion</vocabulary> of your company. Growth can't happen without a little wiggle room.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I enjoy the fragrance of aroma oils after getting out of the bath.
examples.ja: お風呂あがりには、アロマオイルの芳香を楽しみます。

examples.en: Any suggestions on air fresheners for cars?
examples.ja: 車用の芳香剤で何かお勧めはありますか？

examples.en: This wine has a sweet, rich aroma and a slightly bitter taste, but is soft on the palate and easy to drink.
examples.ja: このワインは甘く濃い芳香があり、ほろ苦いけど口にやわらかく飲みやすいです。

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>aromatic</kanji> <kanji>fragrance</kanji> is usually a <vocabulary>fragrance</vocabulary> with a <vocabulary>sweet smell</vocabulary>.

芳香 is a formal word for a pleasant, natural fragrance, like the scent of roses. You'll most likely see this in the word 芳香剤 (air fresheners), but it's also used in literature for pleasant aromas.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The plums' aroma is really fragrant during this season.
examples.ja: この季節は、梅の香りがとても芳しいですね。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. The kanji is <kanji>aromatic</kanji>, so this also means <vocabulary>aromatic</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>fragrant</vocabulary>. 

芳しい is a formal word, often used in writing to describe <vocabulary>sweet-smelling</vocabulary> flowers, tea, or incense. In a figurative sense it can mean "favorable," too, but this meaning mostly appears in the negative form 芳しくない (unfavorable, poorly received).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you want to smell an <vocabulary>aromatic</vocabulary> fragrance, just open some potpourri. But be careful if it's a can. Fragrant <reading>can</reading>s will <reading>baa</reading> (かんば) like a sheep at you when you open them. That can baa is just a sweet smell side effect.

examples.en: How can you say that this degree of hardship is like walking on a thorny path through life?
examples.ja: この程度の苦難で、茨の道を歩んでいるような人生だとか、よく言えるよね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: Despite his youth, my son lacks ambition.
examples.ja: うちの息子は、若いのに覇気が無い。

meaning_mnemonic: If you have the <kanji>leadership</kanji> <kanji>spirit</kanji> it means you have a lot of <vocabulary>ambition</vocabulary> to go after the things you want. And you'll be able to lead others because of it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Our school’s baseball club dominated the autumn league match.
examples.ja: わが校の野球部が、秋のリーグ戦を制覇しました。

meaning_mnemonic: Those with <kanji>leadership</kanji> who want <kanji>control</kanji> will set out on missions of <vocabulary>conquest</vocabulary> and strive for world <vocabulary>domination</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: That man reigns supreme over the party.
examples.ja: あの男が党内の覇権を握っているのです。

meaning_mnemonic: Those with the <kanji>rights</kanji> to <kanji>leadership</kanji> have complete <vocabulary>hegemony</vocabulary> over the country. And they will reign until the end of time.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: They’re the tournament champions from last year.
examples.ja: あいつらが前年度のこの大会の覇者です。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> with the most <kanji>leadership</kanji> is known as the <vocabulary>supreme ruler</vocabulary>. No one has more leadership than them.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Has there been a high school that’s had three successive victories at Koshien yet?
examples.ja: 今までに甲子園を三連覇した高校はありますか？

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>take along</kanji> your <kanji>leadership</kanji> over and over, you're on a <vocabulary>winning streak</vocabulary>! You can expect <vocabulary>successive victories </vocabulary> in <vocabulary>consecutive championships</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for は becoming ぱ.

examples.en: Two pieces of tuna, please.
examples.ja: マグロを二貫ください。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: I ordered just one piece of the highest grade of fatty tuna.
examples.ja: 最高級のトロを一貫だけ注文しました。

examples.en: The hunter consistently said no, and eventually left Japan without having eaten a single piece of sushi.
examples.ja: その猟師は一貫してノーと言い続け、結局一貫も寿司を食べないまま日本を後にした。

examples.en: You have to be consistent with your customers or you will get complaints later.
examples.ja: お客様には一貫した対応を取らないと、後でクレームが来ますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>One</kanji> <kanji>sushi counter</kanji> is counting <vocabulary>one piece of sushi</vocabulary>. This can also mean <vocabulary>consistency</vocabulary>, which makes sense if you think about piece of sushi—each one should be as consistent as the last! Linked to this, it can also mean <vocabulary>integration</vocabulary>, because integration is easier if there's consistency, after all.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My wire bra protected me from the bullet penetrating.
examples.ja: ブラジャーのワイヤーが弾丸の貫通を防いでくれた。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>pierce</kanji> some fabric with a needle it needs to <kanji>pass through</kanji> to the other side to actually <vocabulary>pierce</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>penetrate</vocabulary> it. Make sure it goes all the way through if you want to sew properly.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It was hard, but we were able to carry through with the plan we had decided on together.
examples.ja: 大変だったけど、みんなで決めた計画を貫徹することができた。

examples.en: I regret that I couldn't realize the dream that I had ten years ago.
examples.ja: 十年前の夢を貫徹できなかったことを残念に思います。

examples.en: I’ll do my best to prepare to accomplish my original goals.
examples.ja: 初志貫徹の心構えで頑張ります。

meaning_mnemonic: You have to <kanji>pierce</kanji> this piece of information into your brain until it finally <kanji>penetrate</kanji>s, which takes a lot of <vocabulary>persistence</vocabulary>. Do that and it will be quite the <vocabulary>accomplishment</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Once you've decided on something, you should follow through on it to the end.
examples.ja: 一度決めたことは、最後まで貫くべきだ。

examples.en: She remained silent.
examples.ja: 彼女は沈黙を貫きました。

examples.en: The bullet train pierces through the mountains and connects cities.
examples.ja: 新幹線は山々を貫いて都市を結んでいます。

examples.en: I stayed true to my love for katsudon, and as a result I gained 5 kg in three days.
examples.ja: カツ丼への愛を貫いた結果、3日で5キロ太った。

examples.en: His words pierced my hardened and heavy heart like bullets going through a steel door.
examples.ja: 彼の言葉は、鋼鉄の扉を貫く弾丸のように、重く硬くなっていた私の心を貫いた。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pierce</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to go through</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pierce</vocabulary>.

貫く is a relatively formal word, mostly used in writing. It can mean physically piercing something, but more often it means <vocabulary>to follow through</vocabulary> on your beliefs or goals all the way to the end.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The best way <vocabulary>to go through</vocabulary> someone's mind or a college campus is <reading>to run nude</reading> (つらぬ). So if you really want <vocabulary>to pierce</vocabulary> someone's mind and soul remember this!

examples.en: We built the doghouse by constructing it at top speed.
examples.ja: 突貫工事で犬小屋を建てました。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>stab</kanji> to <kanji>pierce</kanji> something, you’d better do it in a <vocabulary>rush</vocabulary>. If you aren't quick enough, you could get into trouble, so rush forth with a mighty charge.

突貫 means doing something in a rush. It’s usually used in the compound 突貫工事, which means fast but often sloppy construction work. It can also describe charging at an enemy, but that meaning is less common today.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You should be able to claim compensation for that.
examples.ja: それは賠償請求できるはずですよ。

examples.en: Please compensate us for the full amount of the damage.
examples.ja: 被害総額の全額を賠償してください。

examples.en: A person who has entered into a contract as an agent of another person shall be liable to the other party for performance or damages.
examples.ja: 他人の代理人として契約をした者は、相手方に対して履行又は損害賠償の責任を負う。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Compensation</kanji> <kanji>reparation</kanji>s are still <vocabulary>compensation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>reparations</vocabulary>! That's convenient.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We have to think about how to deal with company employees who have committed misconduct.
examples.ja: 不正を行った社員の処遇を考えなくてはいけません。

meaning_mnemonic: You should <kanji>deal with</kanji> and change your <kanji>treatment</kanji> of certain people depending on what kind of situation you're in. This vocab is just the same, making this <vocabulary>dealing with</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>treatment</vocabulary.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I encountered a tragic traffic accident.
examples.ja: 悲惨な交通事故に遭遇しました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji here are <kanji>encounter</kanji> and <kanji>encounter</kanji>, which makes this… <vocabulary>encounter</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Thanks to this card I can taste VIP treatment.
examples.ja: このカードのお陰で、VIP待遇を味わうことができました。

meaning_mnemonic: Just because you have to <kanji>wait</kanji> for special <kanji>treatment</kanji> doesn't mean it's not still good <vocabulary>treatment</vocabulary>. And just because everyone didn't cheer when you arrived, doesn't mean you're getting a cold <vocabulary>reception</vocabulary>, you know? Maybe they're planning a surprise party for you or something... yeah.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We shouldn’t give too much preferential treatment to older people.
examples.ja: 高齢者を優遇しすぎじゃないでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: When you are given <kanji>superior</kanji> <kanji>treatment</kanji> it's called <vocabulary>preferential treatment</vocabulary>. This is the best way to be treated.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If he’s so great then why did he get such a cold reception?
examples.ja: 彼は実力があるのにどうしてこんなに冷遇されているんですか。

meaning_mnemonic: When you are given <kanji>cool</kanji> <kanji>treatment</kanji> it's called a <vocabulary>cold reception</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>inhospitality</vocabulary>. This sucks.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You can’t blame your environment for your own unhappiness.
examples.ja: 自分の不幸を境遇のせいにするんじゃない。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>treatment</kanji> of your <kanji>boundary</kanji> of your neighborhood is something you should be concerned about, because it's your <vocabulary>environment</vocabulary> and if you don't take care of it, who will?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Have you ever encountered blatant racial discrimination?
examples.ja: 露骨な人種差別に遭ったことはありますか。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>encounter</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to encounter</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to meet</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Remember how 会う also means <vocabulary>to meet</vocabulary>? Well they're both read あう too! So if you know that one, you know this one too!

examples.en: We narrowly missed having a disaster.
examples.ja: 危うく遭難するところでした。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>encounter</kanji> something <kanji>difficult</kanji> it's going to result in <vocabulary>disaster</vocabulary>. Especially if you're in a boat. Encountering really difficult water will result in a <vocabulary>shipwreck</vocabulary>! Ick!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: They were tied with chains so they wouldn’t escape.
examples.ja: 逃げないように鎖で繋いでいます。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The best way to break out of the <vocabulary>chains</vocabulary> life puts on you is to put on a <reading>cool sari</reading> (くさり). A cool sari will remind you where you come from. Who your family is. And how beautiful you look. Cast off those chains and put on a cool sari!

examples.en: When was Japan in national isolation?
examples.ja: 日本が鎖国していたのはいつですか。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>country</kanji> in <kanji>chain</kanji>s is under a <vocabulary>national isolation</vocabulary> policy. They're bound and they can't visit anywhere else.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The bank was bankrupted and my account was frozen.
examples.ja: 銀行が潰れて、預金が封鎖されてしまったんです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>seal</kanji>ed <kanji>chain</kanji> won't break or open so it gets in the way of everyone, forming a <vocabulary>blockade</vocabulary>. This can happen at banks too and it will result in them <vocabulary>freezing</vocabulary> your account!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The pool is closed this month.
examples.ja: このプールは今月で閉鎖されます。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>closed</kanji> <kanji>chain</kanji> lets everyone know that a building or store is <vocabulary>closing</vocabulary> for good. It's got to <vocabulary>lockout</vocabulary> everyone so they won't try to get in anymore.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: First, there's a need to break this vicious chain of unfortunate events.
examples.ja: まずはこの負の連鎖を断ち切る必要があります。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>take along</kanji> a <kanji>chain</kanji> with you it's still a <vocabulary>chain</vocabulary>, it's just moving somewhere new.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: At this rate, we're going to end up falling into a price war.
examples.ja: このままでは、価格競争に陥るのがオチですよ。

examples.en: The fire alarm went off, and all the employees fell into panic.
examples.ja: 火災報知器が鳴って、社員全員がパニックに陥った。

examples.en: I get lost easily, so while driving I often find myself in a "Where am I?" situation.
examples.ja: 私は道に迷いやすく、ドライブ中によく「ここどこ？」状態に陥る。

examples.en: The economic crisis worsened, and the country fell into a situation beyond all help.
examples.ja: 経済危機が悪化し、国はなんの手の施しようもない状況に陥った。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>cave in</kanji>, and the verb version takes that feeling further. It means <vocabulary>to fall into</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be thrown into</vocabulary> something negative, like a trap, trouble, or even a bad emotional state.

陥る describes a moment when the world around you or your heart caves in, and you're suddenly thrown into that space and get trapped inside. It's like slipping into a dark hole in life you didn't see coming. That's the feeling!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Whenever you're about <vocabulary>to fall into</vocabulary> a physical or emotional pit of doom, you just mutter, "<reading>Oh chee</reading>se <reading>ea</reading>tery (おちい)..." Because that's where it always starts. You can never resist the temptations of their mysterious fondue. Oh, that cheese eatery is like a trap for people with no self-control. Get ahold of yourself! Your life is falling into cheesy ruin!!

examples.en: It looks like that highway over there collapsed from the earthquake.
examples.ja: 地震であそこの道路が陥没したそうです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>cave in</kanji> where everyone <kanji>die</kanji>s is still a <vocabulary>cave in</vocabulary>, just a really sad one.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why do you think that Toyota fell from being the best in the world?
examples.ja: トヨタが世界一から陥落したのは何故だと思いますか。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>fall</kanji> during a <kanji>cave in</kanji> you'll <vocabulary>fall</vocabulary> along with everything around you. And that <vocabulary>sinking</vocabulary> feeling in your stomach is because... I mean, well you ARE sinking into the ground.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The safety defect in this product was identified by consumers.
examples.ja: 消費者からこの商品の安全性の欠陥が指摘されています。

meaning_mnemonic:
This item is <kanji>lack</kanji>ing a piece, causing its surface to <kanji>cave in</kanji>. What a <vocabulary>defect</vocabulary>!

欠陥 is a relatively formal word that refers to a <vocabulary>fault</vocabulary> in something, whether in a physical object, a system, or even a plan.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I can’t think of anything but cliched lines.
examples.ja: 陳腐な台詞しか思い浮かびません。

meaning_mnemonic: If you keep <kanji>exhibit</kanji>ing the same actions and emotions and phrases eventually they're going to <kanji>rot</kanji> and sound <vocabulary>cliched</vocabulary> to everyone. You have to mix things up once in a while. You don't want to get <vocabulary>stale</vocabulary>, do you?!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for ふ becoming ぷ.

examples.en: What did you think of the bakery’s exposed exhibition?
examples.ja: あなたは、パン屋のむき出しの陳列についてどう思いますか。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>exhibit</kanji> of things in a <kanji>row</kanji> only happens at an <vocabulary>exhibition</vocabulary>. Everything will be neatly lined up on <vocabulary>display</vocabulary> for you there.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: First, the defendant will perform their opening statement.
examples.ja: まず、被告人が冒頭陳述を行います。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Exhibit</kanji> what you want to <kanji>mention</kanji> in a loud, clear <vocabulary>statement</vocabulary>. You have to say it if you want people to listen.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A petition is a system to reflect the opinions and requests of the residents.
examples.ja: 請願・陳情は、住民の意見や要望を反映させるための制度です。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Exhibit</kanji> your <kanji>feeling</kanji>s in a <vocabulary>petition</vocabulary>. If you feel something is unjust you have to say something. Form an <vocabulary>appeal</vocabulary> and fight back!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My favorite motorcycle is the Suzuki Falcon.
examples.ja: 俺の一番好きなバイクは、スズキの隼です。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: By default, you’re required to input your name, birthdate, and email address.
examples.ja: デフォルトでは、名前と生年月日、メールアドレスの入力が必須になっています。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>certain</kanji>ly <kanji>necessary</kanji> is something you can't live without. It's <vocabulary>indispensable</vocabulary>. And it's <vocabulary>required</vocabulary> by you to keep on living.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Akane quickly wiped away the tears.
examples.ja: 茜は颯と涙を拭った。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the adverb version of the kanji <kanji>quick</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>quickly</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This actually uses the kun'yomi reading, but it's almost the same as the one you learned when you learned the kanji. It's just さっ instead of さつ. If you can remember that さつ gets shortened here, you'll know how to read this!

examples.en: I want to slowly soak in the bath.
examples.ja: ゆっくりお風呂に浸かりたいなあ。

meaning_mnemonic: Let the <kanji>wind</kanji> in from the window above your <kanji>bath</kanji> so the water is cool enough for you to take a <vocabulary>bath</vocabulary>! If the water is too hot, you'll get all dizzy and that's dangerous!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. This isn't the same on'yomi reading you learned for 風, though. It's a little different: ふ. If you're taking a <kanji>bath</kanji> you'd be a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ) to bring food in there. Drop the う or you'll end up as soup!

examples.en: I remember playing cat's cradle when I was a child.
examples.ja: 子供の時、綾取りをしていたのを覚えています。

examples.en: The other day, I tried my hand at cat's cradle.
examples.ja: この間、綾取りに挑戦した。

examples.en: Mami taught us various games such as origami and cat's cradle.
examples.ja: マミさんには折り紙や綾取りなどいろいろな遊びを教えてもらいました。

meaning_mnemonic: One <kanji>design</kanji> that you can <kanji>take</kanji> anywhere with you is <vocabulary>cat's cradle</vocabulary>, the game where you loop string around your hands and fingers to create patterns.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi for both kanji.

examples.en: When I was a child, I was friends with a very innocent girl called Ayano.
examples.ja: 子供の頃、綾乃というとても無邪気な女の子と友達だった。

examples.en: Ayano called the other day but she didn't leave a voicemail message.
examples.ja: 先日、綾乃さんから電話があったんですが、留守電にメッセージが入っていなかったんです。

examples.en: Ayano-chan and Ryohei-kun are having a fistfight, but what should I do?
examples.ja: 綾乃ちゃんと亮平君が殴り合いをしているけど、どうしよう。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a <kanji>design</kanji> <kanji>from</kanji> <vocabulary>Ayano</vocabulary>. Do you know an Ayano who's good at designing things? A couple creative Ayanos include traditional Okinawan folk singer and sanshin player Uema Ayano (上間 綾乃), and author Takeda Ayano (武田 綾乃) who won the Yoshikawa Eiji Literary Newcomer Award in 2021.
reading_mnemonic: This name uses the readings that you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I believe that person's spouse is called Daisuke.
examples.ja: その方の配偶者は大輔さんという方だと思います。

examples.en: Daisuke was deeply impressed.
examples.ja: 大輔はとても感銘を受けた。

examples.en: Do you know what Daisuke-kun's family name is?
examples.ja: 大輔君の苗字は何か知ってる？

meaning_mnemonic:
Who's a <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>help</kanji>? That'll be <vocabulary>Daisuke</vocabulary>!

Famous Daisukes include film director and screenwriter Itō Daisuke (伊藤 大輔), figure skater Takahashi Daisuke (髙橋 大輔), and actor and singer Namikawa Daisuke (浪川 大輔).
reading_mnemonic:
This name uses the on'yomi for 大 and the nanori for 輔. You learned both of these with the kanji, so that should be a big help.

Note: Historically, this name can be read たいふ or おおすけ, as is the case for Heian period poet 伊勢大輔, whose name can be read either いせのたいふ or いせのおおすけ. In modern contexts, you'll only need to know だいすけ though, not to worry!

examples.en: Today, I will learn cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
examples.ja: 今日は心肺蘇生法を学びます。

examples.en: I desperately attempted resuscitation.
examples.ja: 私は必死で蘇生を試みました。

examples.en: This book provides detailed information about the magic used to resurrect the dead.
examples.ja: この本では、死者を蘇生する魔術について詳しく書かれています。

examples.en: The new president successfully revived the organization.
examples.ja: 新社長は見事に組織を蘇生させてみせた。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>revive</kanji> <kanji>life</kanji>, what you're doing is <vocabulary>resuscitation</vocabulary>. Or, to be less medical, <vocabulary>revival</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I'm not a fan of shiso.
examples.ja: 私、紫蘇は苦手なんです。

examples.en: I tried planting shiso seeds this year.
examples.ja: 今年は紫蘇の種を植えてみました。

examples.en: It has a really nice shiso aroma, doesn't it?
examples.ja: とてもいい紫蘇の香りがしますね。

meaning_mnemonic:
What could a <kanji>purple</kanji> <kanji>revive</kanji> be? This actually means <vocabulary>shiso</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>Japanese perilla</vocabulary>, and it's a type of herb commonly used in Japanese cuisine. You can remember this refers to a plant by the flowers radical in 蘇. You might also want to google "shiso," as you'll notice how some of them have purple leaves!

Note that, as with other plant and tree species, you'll often encounter this being written in katakana as well.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned 紫's on'yomi reading with 紫外線, but here's a mnemonic in case you forgot:

You know what's really good with <vocabulary>shiso</vocabulary>? <reading>Shee</reading>p (し) meat. Wrap some sheep meat in shiso and pan fry it, or try mixing ground sheep meat with minced shiso to make some tasty meatballs. Yum!
